bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 18, 1900

div1.p: Reed writes that he has found mosquitoes and volunteers for his experiments, and will now proceed with the laboratory work. He comments on newspaper reports about yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 18, 1900
div1.opener:
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba,
Novr 18th 1900.
Sunday.
My sweet, sweet wifie:
div1.p:
Yester-
day's mail brought two nice
letters from the dearest
woman in this wide world,
and one more letter from
the most “preciousest” little
daughter in the U.S - As
I wrote to little daughter,
I believe that I gave
You the wrong days for
writing your letters, and
hence if they haven't come
promptly, it was not
my sweet oomsey's fault!
The boat leaves Tampa on
Mondays, Wednesdays and
Saturdays- Letters there-
fore mailed in Washington
before noon on Tuesdays,
Thursdays & Saturdays should
come right through - day
written the night preceding
& mailed early on the days
given above - But, bless
your sweet heart, don't
bother your darling head
about the days - Write
just when you get ready
and your old Mantee
will get it them after awhile.
Just as a pointer, however,
lovie your letter written
on Tuesday the 13th & Post-
marked 9 P.M Washington
reached me on the morning
of the 17th, and your letter
postmarked Sunday 7.30 P.M.
came at the same time; in
other words Sunday's letter
was too late for Saturdays
boat leaving on Monday night
& which got here last
wednesday- write, there-
fore, sweet joy, on Tuesdays
Thursdays & Saturdays,
and I shall be quite satisfied.
I thought from the tempera-
tures here that you must
be having it cold in the
U.S- Certainly the owner
will see that Miss Mason's
house is well heated.
It wouldn't do at all for
her to give it up, this win-
ter- She had better hang
right on to it till spring,
for the winter may be very
mild after all- Here, at pres-
ent, it is simply, lovely
June weather- The thermom
eter was 76° at breakfast
time, this morning, and if the
breeze wasn't blowing, it
would now be disagreeably
warm- I guess that we
will have all of the warm
weather we want for the
propagation of our mosquitoes.
By searching around in this
immediate neighborhood we
have been able to find
all the Culex fasciatus we
want. Work on our camp
is going along rapidly, and
my experimental houses
will soon be completed.
We already have eight in-
dividuals who are willing
and anxious to undergo
any experiments that we
desire to subject them to.
We will put them in camp tomorrow
& keep tomorrow them there for 7
days before we under-
take any work with them.
We ought thus to be able
to arrive at some final and
positive results. Dr Ames
will have charge of the
experimental station and no
unauthorized person will
be allowed near the camp.
Don't worry about any
exposure on my part, for
I shall do nothing in con-
nection with the camp.
My work is to get the station
completed and properly e-
quipped, & then I shall con-
fine myself to Labora-
tory work. Dr Kean is
invaluable to me - he is
really the quartermaster
of the camp & is doing every-
thing to bring about
a successful issue to
our work- He will re-
main here as Post Surg-
eon & has already taken
quarters in the Post-
Dr & Mrs. Stark will re-
main here certainly
till January 1st & then
probably go to the states.
Wednesday afternoon last
Mrs. Kean & Mrs. Stark gave
a very pretty progressive
Euchre party which was
quite a success. Everybody
in the garrison was there
and we enjoyed ourselves
very much. As the guests
arrived, each was handed
a delicious mint-Julep
which my sweet wifie
would have enjoyed very
much- It was a little heady.
while I playing away at one
of the tables, I felt a slap on
my soldier shoulder, & heard someone
say, “Excuse me, Major, I was
only killing a Mosquito”!
Looking up, I found that
it was Gen. Lee who was
passing by- He is very full
of fun- The General left
Havana on yesterday, re-
ceiving quite an ovation
on his departure- We were
all so sorry to see him go-
and shall miss him very much.
Thursday night quite a brilliant
ball was given by the
7th Cav. in his honor - The
hall is very large and the
decorations with the royal
palm leaves was very beautiful.
Monday morning: Nov. 19. I am very
sorry that my sweet “oomseye”
wasn't feeling very well when
she wrote- Folks will have
pain sometimes in their “Tum-
my's”-! I think that you may
well say that you wouldn't
trust any thing a certain
individual with many wives
should say! Wasn't that per-
fectly dreadful? Don't inti-
mate any opinion you may
have to Miss Carrie- Please
give her my love. Of course,
you Miss me, lovie, dear!
Why shouldn't you? But just
take care of your darling
self and take care of smart
little scholar, and your old Mr
Mantee will come jogging back
after awhile; and we will
go up together to dear Kee-
waydin & your dream shall
be realized - Many thanks
for the clipping you sent-
I was quite interested in it.
I have received a number
of clippings from the N.Y. man-
Some unfavorable, but the major-
ity commendatory- I send a
short cutting from Havana Post
of yesterday- Never mind about
the newspapers, lovie, dear, or
what people don't say - I had
rather for it to not be spoken
of just now- We hope soon to
settle the matter finally. The
Postman is Coming. Good-bye-
Kisses & love & love & kisses
for my sweet, sweet girls-
